choices.B: visibility into IP-based threats by tunneling suspicious IP connections
choices.A: the ability to see all traffic without requiring TLS decryption
choices.C: the ability to dynamically categorize traffic to previously uncategorized sites
choices.D: visibility into traffic that is destined to sites within the office environment

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
The correct answer is B. The Cisco Umbrella roaming client provides an advantage of visibility into IP-based threats by tunneling suspicious IP connections. This allows the client to protect against threats and prevent malware from making connections to attacker-controlled infrastructure, even over non-standard ports.

Selected Answer: B
If we are talking about SWG yes is B.

https://docs.umbrella.com/deployment-umbrella/docs/create-and-apply-policies

Enable IP-Layer Enforcement—For roaming client identities only, tunnels suspect IP connections to gain visibility into threats that bypass DNS lookups. For more information, see Add IP Layer Enforcement.

https://docs.umbrella.com/deployment-umbrella/docs/6-adding-ip-layer-enforcementz

and of course.. its eol july 2022 - wasting time studying on dead topics

Selected Answer: B
Leaning toward B rather than C, because:
 - less likely to be C, as uncategorized traffic is blocked (NOT dynamically learnt) : https://docs.umbrella.com/umbrella-user-guide/docs/manage-content-categories-for-web-policies
 - more likely to be B "Our endpoint footprint simply forwards DNS requests or tunnels to suspicious IP connections to the nearest data center in our global network." https://umbrella.cisco.com/solutions/off-network-endpoint-security
C makes sense

Selected Answer: B
Answer is B (100%)
https://medium.com/swlh/a-study-on-how-cisco-umbrella-roaming-client-works-f3cd552c7112

comments.content:
B. Visibility into IP-based threats by tunneling suspicious IP connections.
This ensures that all devices are protected from malicious activity, regardless of their location.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
It is D

Selected Answer: B
B resonates the most with this statement

These clients protect users from connections to malicious destinations and command-and-control callbacks at the DNS and IP layers, no matter where the device connects to the internet. 

https://umbrella.cisco.com/blog/secure-remote-workers-with-the-cisco-umbrella-roaming-client#:~:text=By%20using%20the%20Umbrella%20roaming,devices%20with%20device%2Dlevel%20reporting.

Selected Answer: B
https://umbrella.cisco.com/solutions/off-network-endpoint-security

comments.content:
Thank you, found this on the link you provided: 
Our endpoint footprint simply forwards DNS requests or tunnels to suspicious IP connections to the nearest data center in our global network. Our simple solution is so powerful because it enables Umbrella to be a virtual “bump-in-the-wire” for every internet connection. We allow good requests. We redirect users to a block page for malicious requests. And we can even proxy connections from risky domains for deeper inspection.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
I go with B. Based on work experience. Below is some documentation:
https://umbrella.cisco.com/blog/opendns-adds-ip-layer-enforcement-umbrella
IP layer enforcement works by checking traffic against a comprehensive list of suspect IP addresses from an OpenDNS threat intelligence database in realtime. If traffic from an endpoint matches an IP from the suspect list, it injects a route to OpenDNS servers and blocks the connection if it is malicious.
I prefer C

Selected Answer: B
I'd choose B.

comments.content: Function you are talking about is inteligent proxy, not roamin client

questions.question_text: What is an advantage of the Cisco Umbrella roaming client?

Which Cisco platform provides an agentless solution to provide visibility across the network including encrypted traffic analytics to detect malware in encrypted traffic without the need for decryption?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
I agree with Felice44. Also a video describing Stealthwatch and ETA: https://video.cisco.com/detail/video/5782606156001

Selected Answer: B
Encrypted Traffic Analytics (ETA)

"Cisco’s proprietary Encrypted Traffic Analytics (ETA) technology uses attributes like Initial Data Packet (IDP) to detect malware in encrypted traffic, without decrypting the data."

https://blogs.cisco.com/security/saas-delivered-encrypted-traffic-analytics-with-cisco-stealthwatch-cloud

A. STIX (Structured Threat Information eXpression) is a language format designed to exchange threat intelligence that can be transported over the TAXII (Trusted Automated eXchange of Indicator Information) protocol. STIX enables organizations to share cyber threat intelligence, such as information about malware, vulnerabilities, and indicators of compromise, in a structured and machine-readable format. It allows for the exchange of information about the cyber threats, including details on the threat actors, their tools, and tactics, techniques and procedures (TTPs).

Selected Answer: A
A - STIX

questions.question_text: What is a language format designed to exchange threat intelligence that can be transported over the TAXII protocol?
Which two Cisco ISE components must be configured for BYOD? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
I go for central webauth and Guest. 

Local webauth has no native support for Byod onboarding, profiling e.t.c

https://www.ciscopress.com/articles/article.asp?p=3100059&seqNum=2#:~:text=Local%20Web%20Authentication%20(LWA)%20is,enter%20a%20username%20and%20password.

Selected Answer: BD
According to this Cisco Article it's B & D:

https://www.ciscopress.com/articles/article.asp?p=3100059&seqNum=2#:~:text=Local%20Web%20Authentication%20(LWA)%20is,enter%20a%20username%20and%20password

comments.content:
Just to add to this so it's clearer, from the article I linked:

In addition, when using Local Web Auth with Cisco switches, there is NO native support for advanced services such as the following:
▪ BYOD onboarding

However, Central Web Auth also supports advanced services such as the following:
▪ BYOD onboarding

Answer is definitely B & D guys, look no further!

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BD
Central webauth, is ISE the one that hast to act here, if is local webauth it would never reach ISE BYOD portal.

Selected Answer: BD
Correct is BD. Here you can see that A and C are not correct:
https://www.ciscopress.com/articles/article.asp?p=3100059&seqNum=2

And I assume that "dual" is used to refer to dual SSID, and here you can see that it's not necessary:
https://community.cisco.com/t5/security-knowledge-base/cisco-ise-byod-prescriptive-deployment-guide/ta-p/3641867#toc-hId--1179912982

And also there you can see the section "configure Guest portal" where it is necessary for the onboarding...
So it's BD

Selected Answer: BD
BD

CWA (Central Web Auth) also supports advanced services such as the following:

 ▪ Client provisioning
 ▪ Posture assessments
 ▪ Acceptable use policies (AUPs)
 ▪ Password changing
 ▪ Self-registration
 ▪ Device registration
---> ▪ BYOD onboarding

# Guest Access Web Authentication Options

Cisco ISE Guest and Web Authentication Services support several deployment options that enable secure guest access. You can provide wired or wireless guest connectivity using **Local or Central Web Authentication** and Device Registration Web Authentication.

questions.question_text: Which system performs compliance checks and remote wiping?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
ISE is not able to perform a remote wipe.

Selected Answer: B
Don't know if every MDM can perform compliance checks. ISE can do both (do compliance checks and perform instruction to wipe device). Cisco mentioned: Cisco ISE allows you to wipe (...) a lost device.

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/security/ise/2-7/admin_guide/b_ise_27_admin_guide/b_ISE_admin_27_secure_wired_access.html#ID727

comments.content:
From the link you provided, Cisco ISE is also being coupled along with MDM (see previous section entitled: Set Up Mobile Device Management Servers with Cisco ISE).

Also, from the same paragraph you're basing your reference from "Cisco ISE allows you to wipe or enable a pin lock for a lost device".....Step 3 also indicates "...From the MDM ACTIONS drop-down list, choose one of the following options: Full Wipe, Corporate Wipe, or Pin Lock."

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
MDM (Mobile Device Management)

Selected Answer: A
A. MDM (Mobile Device Management)
